title: Not Helvetica, what is it?
content:
I need to recreate some T-Mobile collateral and I need to identify this font family. I'm sure this should be obvious to the experts here! Thanks.

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317051441im_/http:/s11.postimg.org/bnogf76b7/TMO_Example.png)  
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317051441im_/http:/s12.postimg.org/gszeog87h/TMO_Example2.png)  
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317051441im_/http:/s30.postimg.org/43wtycdip/TMO_Example3.png)

Font: 

 TeleGrotesk 

Solved By: 

 [Ryuk](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317051441/http:/typophile.com/user/22675 "View user profile.")

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [TMO Example3.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317051441/http:/typophile.com/files/TMO%20Example3.png) | 37.23 KB |
author: 1Gr8Alex

comments.content:
Unfortunately, it's their own corporate typeface called [TeleGrotesk](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317051441/http:/www.urwpp.de/cgi-bin1/dalcgi/source/schnellsuche_e.htd?searchchar=telegrotesk) and made by [URW++](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317051441/http:/www.urw.de/english/fonts/identitype/telekom.html). If you're working officially for them, they should provide you a complete package... If not, try switching with [URW++ Grotesk](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317051441/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/grotesk) Narrow, far from perfect (main big difference is the single storey / [a](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317051441/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/grotesk/urw-grotesk-t-regular-narrow/glyphs.html#glyphs/473308/66)) but could do the job.  
Other alternative: [Founders Grotesk Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317051441/http:/typophile.com/wiki/https%3A/%252Fwww.klim.co.nz/retail-fonts/founders-grotesk-condensed), [Grotesque Display MTI](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317051441/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/grotesque-display-mt)

[TeleGrotesk](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317051441/http:/www.urwpp.de/cgi-bin1/dalcgi/source/schnellsuche_e.htd?searchchar=telekom&submit.x=-151&submit.y=-9&submit=go) custom designed by URW for Deutsche Telekom (T-Mobile parent company).
Ryuk got to this before me, I see.
